pullRequest.body:
- Deprecate `MulChar.IsNontrivial` (following the analogous change for `AddChar`'s a few days ago);
- fix capitalisation of `DirichletCharacter.isPrimitive`; 
- adjust some lemmas to take a `Nat` argument with a `NeZero` instance, rather than a `PNat`, which is more general and flexible.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

</summary>

`+ eq_one_iff`
`+ injective_ringHomComp`
`+ ne_one_iff`
`+ primitive_mul_isPrimitive`
`+ quadraticChar_exists_neg_one'`
`+ quadraticChar_ne_one`
`+ ringHomComp_eq_one_iff`
`+ ringHomComp_ne_one_iff`
`+ sum_eq_zero_of_ne_one`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/no_lost_declarations.sh short <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:

```
</details>

</details>

Can you please make sure that PRs called `feat` contain new content? This is not the case of this one and, since it changes API in a trivial way (everything that could be done before can still be done after with a basically one to one correspondence), it should be `chore` (rather than `refactor`, which would involve changing definitions, refactoring the API...).
Sure, sorry about that, fixed!
maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Thanks!

bors merge

Build failed (retrying...):
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9545483709/job/26306322716)

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9546779195/job/26310352595)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9546779195/job/26310353092)
LGTM!
LGTM!

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion def IsNontrivial.sum_eq_zero [IsDomain R'] {χ : MulChar R R'} (hχ : χ.IsNontrivial) : ∑ a, χ a = 0 := ```
Dot notation was a benefit of `IsNontrivial` ...

Indeed, that's true; but there's a tradeoff against having to cook up an `IsNontrivial` type when you want to apply the lemmas. In my ongoing Dirichlet-L-series project I found `\chi \ne 1` to be an easier hypothesis to work with, and Yael seems to have found the same in the add-char context.

```suggestion
  have : NeZero (n : F') := ⟨h⟩
```
The Lean4 "I" has nothing to do with instances, and without it it is actually marginally faster.
Yes, I don't really know why the porting scripts changed Lean3 `haveI` to lean4 `haveI` even though it means something different.

I would prefer
```lean
  by_cases hF : ringChar F = 2
  · have h := FiniteField.even_card_of_char_two hF
    simp only [FiniteField.isSquare_of_char_two hF, true_iff_iff]
    omega
  · have h := FiniteField.odd_card_of_char_ne_two hF
    rw [← quadraticChar_one_iff_isSquare (Ring.two_ne_zero hF), quadraticChar_two hF,
      χ₈_nat_eq_if_mod_eight]
    omega
```
I think the juggling around with the goals is more confusing than having two `omega`s.
Same here.

This is needed (at least) twice. Add a lemma
```lean
lemma quadraticChar_exists_neg_one' (hF : ringChar F ≠ 2) : ∃ a : Fˣ, quadraticChar F a = -1
```
in `NumberTheory.LegendreSymbol.QuadraticChar.Basic`?
See below (or above, depending on how you view it) in `...QuadraticChar.GaussSum`.

```suggestion
  simp only [ext_iff, one_apply_coe]
```

```suggestion
lemma ringHomComp_ne_one_iff {f : R' →+* R''} (hf : Function.Injective f) {χ : MulChar R R'} :
    χ.ringHomComp f ≠ 1 ↔ χ ≠ 1 :=
  (ringHomComp_eq_one_iff hf).not
```
Is it common to have both equivalences in Mathlib?
I was following Yaël's treatment of `AddChar` which also has both. If we're using this in rewrites, it will be annoying to unfold the definition of `≠`.
I agree it's more convenient for rewriting (although one could use `rw [(ringHomComp_eq_one_iff hf).not]`).

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - chore(NumberTheory/MulChar): deprecate `IsNontrivial`, fix `isPrimitive`
